* Create a new workflow in the workflows app and give it the name:
``````
AWS Ec2 remediate cpu saturation
``````
* In the workflow settings, set the workflow actor to the available service-user
* Change the trigger task to "Davis Problem trigger"
* In the trigger settings choose the event category "Resource"
* Paste the following filter query into the "Additional custom filter query" field:

``````
matchesPhrase(cloud.provider, "aws") and matchesPhrase(event.name, "Process Cpu Saturation") and maintenance.is_under_maintenance==false and dt.davis.is_duplicate==false and matchesPhrase(entity_tags, "Dynatrace-SSM-Action-Demo_"+input[ "awsaccountid" ]+"")  
``````
* Click the "Query Past Events" button to see if this filters for the Problem you are trying to remediate
* Set the trigger task to inactive for now
* Add a new task by clicking on the plus sign of the trigger task and choose "Run Workflow" from the actions menu
* In the Run Workflow field, search for: 
``````
template - dynatrace remediate aws ec2 instance process or memory saturation
``````
* Name the task:
``````
run-aws-ec2-process-saturation-remediation
``````
* This is a reusable template, standardizing Business resilience within our oranization
* Comparing the input field parameters of the template and the problem event details with each other, shows that we are missing some information needed to run the template!
  * The fields we are missing are:
  * AWS Instance ID
  * The Process name of the Process consuming to much resources
  * The Dynatrace host id that the Process runs on
  * The Ec2 Instance Type
  * The AWS Region in which the host resides
  * The AWS Account id/Dynatrace Connection Name
* We need to add tasks to get that information first and then hand the information over as variables to the template task execution
* Click the 3 dots of the tasks and choose "disable task" to disable it for now
* We are going to add a new task that will get us the entire information of the problem event and the following parameters that our template needs
  * The Process name of the Process consuming to much resources  
* Add a new task by clicking on the plus sign of the trigger task and choose "Run Workflow" from the actions menu
* In the Run Workflow field, search for: 
``````
subworkflow - dynatrace get all problem data
``````
* In the input field enter:
``````
{
"event.id":"{{event()["event.id"] }}"
}
``````
* Name the task:
``````
get-problem-info
``````
* Test the workflow by running it manually, make sure the task "get-problem-info" executes successfully (green)
* Have a look at the result of the workflow and look for "affectedEntities - name" that is the value for the parameter process name that we need
* That gives us 1 parameter, we still need all the rest of the parameters:
* The Parameters we are missing are:
  * AWS Instance ID
  * The Process name of the Process consuming to much resources
  * The Dynatrace host id that the Process runs on
  * The Ec2 Instance Type
  * The AWS Region in which the host resides
  * The AWS Account id/Dynatrace Connection Name
* We will get all of these with the next task
* Add another "run workflow task" right after get-problem-info by clicking the plus sign
* In the Run Workflow field, search for: 
``````
subworkflow - aws get host data of ec2 instance
``````
* In the input field enter:
``````
{
"host_entity_id":"{{event()["dt.entity.host"][0] }}"
}
``````
* Name the task: 
``````
get-aws-host-data
``````
* Test the workflow by running it manually, make sure all tasks execute successfully (green)
* Have a look at the result of the get-aws-host-data task, we get all the info that we need!
* Now go back to task "run-aws-ec2-process-saturation-remediation" that triggers our template and enter the following into the input field:
``````
{
  "event_id": "{{event()["event.id"] }}",
  "display_id": "{{event()["display_id"] }}",
  "event_name": "{{event()["event.name"] }}",
  "instance_id": "{{result("get-aws-host-data")['ec2_awsInstanceId'] }}",
  "process_name": "{{result("get-problem-info").affectedEntities[0].name }}",
  "process_entity_id": "{{result("get-problem-info").affectedEntities[0].entityId.id }}",
  "process_host_name": "{{result("get-aws-host-data")['entity.name'] }}",
  "process_host_entity_id": "{{result("get-aws-host-data")['id'] }}", 
  "ec2_instance_type": "{{result("get-aws-host-data")['ec2_awsInstanceType'] }}",
  "aws_region_name": "{{result("get-aws-host-data")['ec2_regionName'] }}",
  "dynatraceawsconnection": "{{result("get-aws-host-data")['awsaccountid']  }}"
}
``````
* Change the tasks position to after the "get-aws-host-data" task and draw a new line between "get-aws-host-data" and "run-aws-ec2-process-saturation-remediation" by clicking and holding the plus sign on the "get-aws-host-data" task and pull it to the "run-aws-ec2-process-saturation-remediation" task. 
* Click on the 3 dots of the "run-aws-ec2-process-saturation-remediation" task and enable it!
* Run the workflow with the last problem event (click on query past events before running it manually)
* If the workflow ran successfully activate the Problem Trigger and click on the Deploy button!
* Congratulations you have completed the first Part of the Hands On Training!

* Create a new workflow in the workflows app and give it the name:
``````
AWS Security remediate public S3 Bucket
``````
* In the workflow settings, set the workflow actor to the available service-user
* Change the trigger task to "Davis Problem trigger"
* In the trigger settings choose the event category "custom"
* Paste the following filter query into the "Additional custom filter query" field:
``````
matchesPhrase(event.name, "*S3 Bucket with Block Public Access set to false detected*") and matchesPhrase(event.name, "*"+mailname+"*)") 
``````
* Click the "Query Past Events" button to see if this filters for the Problem you are trying to remediate
* Set the trigger task to inactive for now
* Click on plus sign of the trigger task
* in the actions menu search for the AWS action:
``````
s3 put public access block
``````
* Name the task:
``````
s3-put-public-access-block
``````
* Have a look at the parameter settings of the aws action 
* To run it we need the following Parameters of the S3 Bucket the problem was raised for:
  * The AWS Connection/Account ID
  * The AWS region the S3 Bucket resides in
  * The Bucket name
  * And the PublicAccessBlockConfiguration
* Unfortunately the event trigger information does not contain any of these values
* So we again have to add tasks to get that information
* Click the 3 dots of the task to deactivate it for now
* Add a new task by clicking on the plus sign of the trigger task and choose "Execute DQL Query" from the actions menu
* In the DQL Query field enter the following DQL:
``````
Fetch dt.davis.events
| filter event.id == "{{event()["event.id"] | replace("V2", "") }}"
``````
* Name the task:
``````
get-additional-event-fields
``````
* Test the workflow by running it manually, make sure the task "get-additional-event-fields" executes successfully (green)
* Now place the "s3-put-public-access-block" task under the "get-additional-event-fields" task, click the plus sign and hold it and pull it over the "s3-put-public-access-block" task
* Put the Connenction field into "expression mode" and enter the Jinja expression:
``````
{% set awsconnection = result("get-additional-event-fields").records[0]['awsaccountid'] %}
{{ connection('builtin:hyperscaler-authentication.connections.aws', awsconnection) }}
``````
* Enter the following into the "Region" field:
``````
{{result("get-additional-event-fields").records[0].aws_region}}
``````
* Enter the following into the "Bucket" field:
``````
{{result("get-additional-event-fields").records[0].S3bucketname}}
``````
* Enter the following into the "PublicAccessBlockConfiguration" field
``````
{ 
  "RestrictPublicBuckets": ["true"],
  "BlockPublicAcls": ["true"],
  "IgnorePublicAcls": ["true"],
  "BlockPublicPolicy": ["true"]
}
``````
* Click on the 3 dots of the "s3-put-public-access-block" task and enable it!
* Add a sub-workflow by clicking the plus sign of "s3-put-public-access-block" choose run workflow task
* In the Run Workflow field, search for: 
``````
subworkflow - dynatrace ingest custom info event
``````
* In the input field enter:
``````
{
"title":"Remediation - ({{event()["display_id"]}} {{event()["event.name"]}}) block public access for S3 Bucket {{result("get-additional-event-fields").records[0].S3bucketname}} in {{result("get-additional-event-fields").records[0].aws_region}}",
"properties":{
"workflow":"{{ environment().url }}/ui/apps/dynatrace.automations/executions/{{ execution().id }}",
"remediation_step":"block public access to S3 Bucket",
"aws_region":"{{result("get-additional-event-fields").records[0].aws_region}}"
}
}
``````
* Name the task:
``````
ingest-remediation-event
``````
* Add another "run workflow task" right after ingest-remediation-event
* In the Run Workflow field, search for: 
``````
subworkflow - dynatrace close problem
``````
* In the input field enter:
``````
{
  "event.id": "{{event()["event.id"]}}"
}
``````
* Name the task:
``````
close-alert
``````
* Run the workflow with the last problem event (click on query past events before running it manually)
* If the workflow ran successfully activate the Problem Trigger and click on the Deploy button!
* Congratulations you have completed the Second Part of the Hands On Training!" } ] }
  let content_blob = new Blob([JSON.stringify(content, null, 2)], {
    type: 'application/json',
  });
  let config = {
    "body": {
      "name": "Perform Workflow Training Day Part 1 "+input.awsaccountid+"",
      "type": "notebook",
      "content": content_blob
      }
  }; 
  let dashboard_url =""
  await new Promise(resolve => setTimeout(resolve, 10000));
  try {
      let create = await documentsClient.createDocument(config);  
      console.log(create)
      console.log(create.id)
      dashboard_url = getEnvironmentUrl()+"/ui/apps/dynatrace.dashboards/dashboard/"+ create.id;  
      let share = await environmentSharesClient.createEnvironmentShare({
        id: create.id,
        body: { documentId: create.id, access: "read" },
      }); 
    
    } catch (error: unknown) {
        console.error("An error occurred:");
        console.error("Error Name:", error.name);
        console.error("Error Message:", error.message);
        console.error("Error Stack:", error.stack); // Provides a stack trace for debugging
        throw new Error("Share not successful rerun!");
  }

* Create a new workflow in the workflows app and give it the name:
``````
AWS EBS remediate low storage
``````
* In the workflow settings, set the workflow actor to the available service-user
* Change the Trigger task to "Davis Problem trigger"
* Choose event category Resource
* Paste the following into the "Additional custom filter query" field:
``````
matchesPhrase(cloud.provider, "aws") and matchesPhrase(event.name, "Low storage warning") and maintenance.is_under_maintenance==false and dt.davis.is_duplicate==false and matchesPhrase(entity_tags, ""+input[ "awsaccountid" ]+"")   
``````
* Click the "Query Past Events" button to see if this filters for the Problem you are trying to remediate
* Set the trigger task to inactive for now
* Click on the plus sign of the trigger task, and choose "Run Workflow" from the actions menu
* In the Run Workflow field, search for: 
``````
template - aws volume remediation
``````
* Name the task:
``````
remedate-low-disk-space
``````
* This is a reusable template, standardizing Business resilience within our oranization
* Comparing the input field parameters of the template and the problem event details with each other, shows that we are missing some information needed to run the template!
* The fields we are missing are:
  * The AWS volume_id
  * The Ec2 Instance Id
  * The future disk size
  * The current disk size
  * The Dynatrace Ec2 Entity Id
  * The Dynatrace AWS Volume Entity ID
  * The Dynatrace Host entity ID
  * The AWS Region
  * The OS Type
  * The AWS Account id/Dynatrace Connection Name
  * the Ebs Name
* We need to add tasks to get that information first and then hand the information over as variables to the template task execution
* Click the 3 dots of the tasks and choose "disable task" to disable it for now
* We are going to add a new task that will get us the AWS Information we need to run the template execution task
* Click on the plus sign of the trigger task, and choose "Run Workflow" from the actions menu
* In the Run Workflow field, search for: 
``````
subworkflow - aws get host data of ec2 instance
``````
* In the input field enter:
``````
{
"host_entity_id":"{{event()["dt.entity.host"][0] }}"
}
``````
* Name the task:
``````
get-aws-host-data
``````
* Test the workflow by running it manually, make sure all tasks execute successfully (green)
* Have a look at the result of the get-aws-host-data task, we now have:
  * The AWS volume_id
  * The Ec2 Instance Id
  * The current disk size
  * The Dynatrace Ec2 Entity Id
  * The Dynatrace AWS Volume Entity ID
  * The Dynatrace Host entity ID
  * The AWS Region
  * The OS Type
  * The AWS Account id/Dynatrace Connection Name
  * the Ebs Name
* We are still missing:
  * The future disk size
* To get this information, we have to add a forecast to find out what the expected disk size will be in 6 hours, because we can only extend an AWS Volume once every 6 hours and want to avoid a business outage
* Add another "run workflow task" right after get-aws-host-data
* In the Run Workflow field, search for: 
``````
subworkflow - aws davis forecast for aws volume usage
``````
* In the input field enter:
``````
{
  "host_entity_id":"{{event()["dt.entity.host"][0] }}",
  "forecast_method": "upper",
  "on_forecast_failure_increase_by_percentag_of_total_diskspace": 100
}
``````
* Name the task:
``````
davis-disk-forecast
``````
* Test the workflow by running it manually, make sure all tasks execute successfully (green)
* Have a look at the result of the davis-disk-forecast task, we now have all the information that we need!
* Now go back to task "AWS EBS remediate low storage" that triggers our template and enter the following into the input field:
``````
{
  "event_id": "{{event()["event.id"] }}",
  "host_name": "{{ event()["host.name"][0] }}",
  "volume_id": "{{result("get-aws-host-data").volumeid }}",
  "display_id": "{{event()["display_id"] }}",
  "instance_id": "{{result("get-aws-host-data")['ec2_awsInstanceId']}}",
  "escalation_email": ""+input[ "awsaccountid" ]+"",
  "future_disk_size": "{{result("davis-disk-forecast").predicted_disk_size }}",
  "current_disk_size": "{{result("get-aws-host-data")['total_disk_size']}}", 
  "ec2_entity_id": "{{result("get-aws-host-data")['ec2_id']  }}",
  "volume_entity_id": "{{result("get-aws-host-data")['ebs_id']  }}",
  "host_entity_id": "{{result("get-aws-host-data")['id']  }}",
  "aws_region": "{{ result("get-aws-host-data")['ec2_regionName']  }}",
  "osType" : "{{result("get-aws-host-data").osType}}",
  "dynatraceawsconnection": "{{result("get-aws-host-data")['awsaccountid']  }}",
  "ebs_name": "{{result("get-aws-host-data").ebs_name }}"
}

``````
* Change the tasks position to after the "get-aws-host-data" task and draw a new line between "get-aws-host-data" and "AWS EBS remediate low storage" by clicking and holding the plus sign on the "get-aws-host-data" task and pull it to the "AWS EBS remediate low storage" task. 
* Click on the 3 dots of the "AWS EBS remediate low storage" task and enable it!
* Run the workflow with the last problem event (click on query past events before running it manually)
* If the workflow ran successfully activate the Problem Trigger and click on the Deploy button!
* Congratulations you have completed the first Part of the Hands On Training!

* Create a new workflow in the workflows app and give it the name:
``````
AWS remediate public security groups
``````
* In the workflow settings, set the workflow actor to the available service-user
* Change the trigger task to "Davis Problem trigger"
* In the trigger settings choose the event category "custom"
* Paste the following filter query into the "Additional custom filter query" field:
``````
matchesPhrase(event.name, "AWS Security group*") and matchesPhrase(event.name, "allows traffic on*") and matchesPhrase(event.name, ""+mailname+"*")
``````
* Click the "Query Past Events" button to see if this filters for the Problem you are trying to remediate
* Set the trigger task to inactive for now
* Click on the plus sign of the trigger task, and choose "Run Workflow" from the actions menu
* In the Run Workflow field, search for: 
``````
subworkflow - aws disable public access for security group
``````
* Name the task:
``````
disable-public-access-for-security-group
``````
* This is a reusable template, standardizing Business resilience within our oranization
* Comparing the input field parameters of the template and the problem event details with each other, shows that we are missing some information needed to run the template!
* The fields we are missing are:
  * The AWS Region
  * the Ip Address to Block
  * The Aws Security Group ID
  * The Dynatrace AWS connection/Account ID
* We need to add tasks to get that information first and then hand the information over as variables to the template task execution
* Click the 3 dots of the tasks and choose "disable task" to disable it for now
* We are going to add a new task that will get us the missing information from the event
* Click on the plus sign of the trigger task, and choose "Execute DQL Query" from the actions menu
* In the DQL Query field enter the following DQL:
``````
Fetch dt.davis.events
| filter event.id == "{{event()["event.id"] | replace("V2", "") }}"
``````
* Name the task:
``````
get-all-event-info
``````
* Test the workflow by running it manually, make sure the task "get-all-event-info" executes successfully (green)
* Have a look at the result of the task "get-all-event-info" you will find it has all the information that our template execution task needs
* Now go back to task "disable-public-access-for-security-group" that triggers our template and enter the following into the input field:
``````
{
  "awsregion": "{{result("get-all-event-info")["records"][0]["region"] }}",
  "ipaddresstoblock": "{{result("get-all-event-info")["records"][0]["cidrIp"] }}",
  "awssecuritygroupid": "{{result("get-all-event-info")["records"][0]["GroupId"] }}",
  "dynatraceawsconnection": "{{result("get-all-event-info")["records"][0]["awsaccountid"]}}"
}
``````
* Change the tasks position to after the "get-all-event-info" task and draw a new line between "get-all-event-info" and "disable-public-access-for-security-group" by clicking and holding the plus sign on the "get-all-event-info" task and pull it to the "disable-public-access-for-security-group" task. 
* Click on the 3 dots of the "disable-public-access-for-security-group" task and enable it!
* Add a "run workflow task" right after disable-public-access-for-security-group
* In the Run Workflow field, search for: 
``````
subworkflow - dynatrace ingest custom info event
``````
* In the input field enter:
``````
{
"title":"Remediation - ({{event()["display_id"]}}) disable public-access for security group {{result("get-all-event-info")["records"][0]["GroupId"] }}/{{result("get-all-event-info")["records"][0]["GroupName"] }} in {{result("get-all-event-info")["records"][0]["region"] }}",
"properties":{
"workflow":"{{ environment().url }}/ui/apps/dynatrace.automations/executions/{{ execution().id }}",
"remediation_step":"disable public-access for security group",
"aws_region":"{{result("get-all-event-info")["records"][0]["region"] }}"
}
}
``````
* Name the task:
``````
ingest-remediation-event
``````
* Add another "run workflow task" right after ingest-remediation-event
* In the Run Workflow field, search for: 
``````
subworkflow - dynatrace close problem
``````
* In the input field enter:
``````
{
  "event.id": "{{event()["event.id"]}}"
}
``````
* Name the task:
``````
close-problem
``````
* Run the workflow with the last problem event (click on query past events before running it manually)
* If the workflow ran successfully activate the Problem Trigger and click on the Deploy button!
* Congratulations you have completed the second Part of the Hands On Training!
